headline.main: The Worst Meal of the Year

docs.abstract: Roy Strong Op-Ed article describes British Christmas food, 'heaviest and most indigestible' of entire year, as moment when British relive history (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: ''If I had my way and I shan't,'' wrote that doyenne of British food writers, Elizabeth David, ''my Christmas Day eating and drinking would consist of an omelet and cold ham and a nice bottle of wine at lunchtime, and a smoked salmon sandwich with a glass of Champagne on a tray in bed in the evening.'' Ah, wouldn't that be bliss! Like Thanksgiving in the United States, Christmas in Britain has grown into an inescapable culinary dinosaur from which you chicken out at your peril -- even in an era when a new, lighter British cuisine is being promoted by young chefs like Jamie Oliver. Families, the majority of which are better kept apart, are suddenly thrown together for a ritual feast lasting several days, plowing their way through a few million roast turkeys, mince pies and Christmas puddings and cakes, not to mention swimming the alcohol lake. I suppose if I had to raise a flag for Christmas food, by far the heaviest and most indigestible of the entire year, it would be because it is one of those moments when the British relive history. Each of those dishes that spell Christmas has an honorable pedigree. In the 1600's, Samuel Pepys recorded in his diary that he was given a turkey for Christmas on no less than four occasions and it was the task of the luckless Mrs. Pepys to kill the creature as the kitchen maid refused. It wasn't, I admit, necessarily eaten on the day but certainly during the festive period. Indeed if we turn to Parson Woodforde's diary a century later Christmas dinner was generally graced by a sirloin of roast beef as its centerpiece. And Woodforde lived in Norfolk, the county that produced the best turkeys, which were driven, poor things, all the way to London to be slaughtered.

headline.main: A Small-Scale Attack on Urban Despair

docs.abstract: Meg Campbell opened Codman Academy charter school three years ago in Boston (Mass) as center for predominantly poor and black children to experience educational advantages that students in upper-middle-class families experience; photos (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: Meg Campbell has banned French fries and fast food from Codman Academy, the small charter high school she opened here three years ago. Her students, who are overwhelmingly poor and black, eat fresh fruit and veggie burgers. With Ms. Campbell pushing them, they walk up to 10 miles a week and play tennis. Back in middle school, in classes of 30, most of the students were reading well below grade level, and many were getting D's and F's. Now, in classes of 15, they are taking on Shakespeare, James Joyce and Chinua Achebe.

headline.main: F.D.A. Moves to Let Drug Treat Obese Teenagers

byline.original: By ANAHAD O'CONNOR and DENISE GRADY

docs.abstract: Food and Drug Administration approves use of obesity drug Xenical for adolescents; it is first time that weight-loss drug has been approved to treat children; drug's maker Hoffman-La Roche says it has no plans to market drug for teenagers; drug works by blocking body's ability to digest fat and is considered by experts to be moderately useful; side effects noted; action comes as studies show 15 percent of American children are overweight; decision to approve drug for children is based on two studies (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: The Food and Drug Administration effectively approved the use of an obesity drug, Xenical, for adolescents yesterday. This is the first time that a weight-loss drug has been permitted to treat overweight children. A spokeswoman for the drug agency said it had decided to allow the manufacturer to add to the Xenical labels two studies that involved children to help doctors prescribe the correct doses for 12- to 16-year-olds.
